ai-ud3.6:1.2_0: At one time the Buddha was staying near Rājagaha, in the Bamboo Grove, the squirrels’ feeding ground.
ai-ud3.6:1.3_0: Now at that time Venerable Pilindavaccha addressed the mendicants as “lowlifes”.
ai-ud3.6:1.4_0: Then several mendicants went up to the Buddha.
ai-ud3.6:1.4_1: After bowing down to the Buddha, they sat down,
ai-ud3.6:1.6_0: “Sir, Venerable Pilindavaccha addresses the mendicants as ‘lowlifes’.”
ai-ud3.6:2.1_0: Then the Buddha addressed a certain mendicant:
ai-ud3.6:2.2_0: “Please, monk, in my name tell the mendicant Pilindavaccha that the Teacher summons him.”
ai-ud3.6:3.1_0: “Yes, reverend,” Pilindavaccha replied. He went to the Buddha, and said to him:
ai-ud3.6:3.3_0: “Is it really true, Vaccha, that you addressed the mendicants as ‘lowlifes’?”
ai-ud3.6:4.1_0: Then, having applied his mind to Pilindavaccha’s past lives, the Buddha said to the mendicants,
ai-ud3.6:4.2_0: “Mendicants, don’t complain about the mendicant Vaccha.
ai-ud3.6:4.3_0: He doesn’t addresses the mendicants as ‘lowlifes’ out of hate.
ai-ud3.6:4.4_0: A mendicant who has previously been born in a brahmin lady of the five hundred pairs can stand before.
ai-ud3.6:4.5_0: For a long time, he has addressed people as ‘lowlife’.
ai-ud3.6:4.6_0: That’s why he addresses the mendicants as ‘lowlifes’.”
ai-ud3.6:5.1_0: Knowing the meaning of this, on that occasion the Buddha expressed this heartfelt sentiment:
ai-ud3.6:6.1_0: “In whom dwells no deceit or conceit,
ai-ud3.6:6.2_0: rid of greed, unselfish, with no need for hope,
ai-ud3.6:6.4_0: they are a brahmin, an ascetic, a mendicant.”
